case_name: Brig. F.J. Dillon v. Major S.S. Khanna

facts.text: Brig. F.J. Dillon and Major S.S. Khanna carried on business in partnership as Construction Engineers.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH, J.-Brig. F.J. Dillon and Major S.S. Khanna hereinafter called Dillon and Khanna respectively carried on business in partnership as Construction Engineers.

facts.text: Dillon and Khanna agreed to dissolve the partnership with effect from February 15, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: They agreed to dissolve the partnership with effect from February 15, 1956. By the deed of dissolution it was agreed that Dillon was to take over all the assets

facts.text: By the deed of dissolution, Dillon was to take over all assets and properties of the partnership as absolute owner, pay all debts, discharge liabilities, and indemnify Khanna.

anchor.surface_text: By the deed of dissolution it was agreed that Dillon was to take over all the assets and properties of the partnership as absolute owner and to pay all the debts and to discharge all the liabilities of the partnership and to keep Khanna indemnified against all demands and claims in relation to the partnership business.

facts.text: Khanna commenced an action against Dillon in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, 1st Class, Delhi for dissolution of the partnership and rendition of accounts.

anchor.surface_text: But the deed did number terminate the disputes between the partners, and Khanna companymenced an action against Dillon in the Court of the Subordinate judge, 1st Class, Delhi for dissolution of the partnership and rendition of accounts.

facts.text: On January 12, 1957, the parties arrived at a compromise incorporated into a decree confirming dissolution subject to winding up scheme.

anchor.surface_text: On January 12, 1957, the parties arrived at a companypromise  which was incorporated into a decree of the Court  companyfirming the earlier dissolution of the partnership, subject to a scheme of winding up, under which all outstanding realised from the debtors of the firm and the sale proceeds of certain assets were to go into a banking account to be opened in the joint names of Dillon and Khanna

facts.text: Under the compromise decree, realizations from debtors and sale proceeds into joint account of Dillon and Khanna, first to liabilities, balance to Dillon.

anchor.surface_text: and were to be applied in the first instance to meet the liabilities of the dissolved firm, and the balance in that joint account was to belong to Dillon.

facts.text: Some outstandings of the dissolved partnership were collected by Dillon and deposited in the joint account.

anchor.surface_text: Some outstanding of the dissolved partnership were companylected by Dillon and were deposited in the joint account of Dillon and Khanna.

facts.text: Dillon filed a suit in Subordinate Judge Delhi for Rs. 54,250 with interest, alleging advances of Rs. 46,000 in three sums between May 1957 and November 1957 at Khanna's request as short-term loans which Khanna failed to repay.

anchor.surface_text: Dillon filed a suit in the Court of the Subordinate judge at Delhi for a decree for Rs. 54,250.00 with future interest alleging that between the months of May 1957 and November 1957 he had, at the request of Khanna, advanced in three sums an aggregate amount of Rs. 46,000.00 as short- term loans which Khanna had promised to but had failed to repay.

facts.text: Khanna pleaded that he did not borrow any loans from Dillon and that the amounts were advanced out of joint funds belonging to both partners.

anchor.surface_text: Khanna pleaded that he did number borrow any loans- from Dillon, and that the amounts claimed in the action being advanced, even on the pled of Dillon. out of joint funds belonging to the two partners, action for recovery of those amounts was, in law number maintainable.

facts.text: Trial Court tried third issue as preliminary: suit not maintainable as partner against partner of dissolved firm in winding up from partnership assets.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the issues raised by the Trial Court in the suit the third,issue viz Whether this suit is number maintainable and the plaintiff is number entitled to institute this suit, as alleged in paras Nos. 15, 16, 17, 18 of the written statement was at the request of Khanna tried as a preliminary issue, and it was held that the suit being by a partner against another partner of a dissolved firm which was in the process of winding up, and in respect of advances from the partnership assets, was number maintainable.

facts.text: Punjab High Court in Civil Revision Nos. 525 and 526-D of 1960 set aside the trial court order and directed the suit be heard according to law.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 320 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 26, 1962, of the Punjab High Court at Delhi in Civil Revision Nos. 525 and 526-D of 1960.

facts.text: Khanna preferred appeal to Supreme Court by special leave in Civil Appeal No. 320 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Punjab in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction set aside the order, and directed that the suit be heard and disposed of according to law. With special leave this appeal is preferred by Khanna.

facts.text: There are two suits by Dillon against Khanna for recovery of Rs. 46,000.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals arise out of two suits which were filed by Dillon against Khanna for recovery of certain amounts aggregating to Rs. 46,000/- and interest

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on August 14, 1963 by Shah J with Hidayatullah J separate opinion.

anchor.surface_text: August 14, 1963. The judgment of A.K. Sarkar and J.C. Shah, JJ., was delivered by Shah, J. M. Hidayatullah, J.delivered a separate Opinion.

facts.text: Trial judge held suits not maintainable but set them down for future date instead of dismissing.

anchor.surface_text: the decision of the trial judge was in favour of Khanna in both the suits. The trial judge held that the suits? were number maintainable, but, instead of dismissing the suits there and then, he set them down for a future date.

facts.text: Dillon recovered assets under compromise on behalf of himself and under power of attorney from Khanna.

anchor.surface_text: Under the companypromise, Dillon was required to recover the assists, companyvert them into cash and put them into a joint account number only on behalf of himself but under a power of attorney from Khanna also on the latters behalf,

facts.text: Khanna contested suits alleging money from joint account, suits between partners not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: Khanna companyntered the suits by companytending that as the money was still in the joint names of the two partners, the suits between partners were number maintainable.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 321 of 1963 also involved with one hearing fee.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts. There will be one hearing fee for this appeal and also C.A. 321 of 1963.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Trial court decided issue on pleadings assuming defendant's allegations true without evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In proceeding to decide the third issue merely on the pleadings and on the assumption that the allegations made by the defendant in his written statement were true and those made by the plaintiff were number true,

facts.text: Khanna pleaded in paras 15-18 of written statement that no personal loan, joint funds, suit not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: Dillon alleged in his plaint that at the request of Khanna, he had advanced diverse loans  from the funds lying in deposit in the joint account  and that the latter had agreed to repay the loans. ... By paragraph 16 he pleaded that Dillon having admitted in the plaint that the amounts in suit were to be paid back to the joint account he was number entitled to file the suit.

facts.text: Dillon advanced amounts from joint account but as loans to Khanna per High Court view.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the opinion that the suits were plainly to recover the amounts borrowed by Khanna from the joint account. The High Court was right in this.

facts.text: Partnership dissolved in February 1956 per Hidayatullah J.

anchor.surface_text: Khanna  the appellant  and Dillon  the respondent  entered into a partnership to do business but in February 1956, they agreed to dissolve it.

facts.text: Deed drawn up where Dillon takes assets and liabilities, indemnifies Khanna.

anchor.surface_text: A deed was drawn up and it was agreed that Dillon was to take over all the assets and liabilities of the partnership keeping Khanna indemnified from all liability.

holdings.text: The expression 'case' in section 115 CPC includes interlocutory orders or proceedings relating to rights and obligations of parties, even if not finally disposing of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: One view which is accepted by a majority of the High Courts is that the expression case includes an interlocutory proceeding relating to the rights and obligations of the parties, and the expression record of any case includes so much of the proceeding as relates to the order disposing of the interlocutory proceeding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and historical interpretation of s.115 as supervisory jurisdiction analogous to prerogative writs; majority High Court view accepted over minority; necessary to prevent injustice.

holdings.text: High Court's revisional jurisdiction under s.115 CPC is not excluded merely because an appeal lies from the final decree or order in the suit.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon the Use of the expression in which numberappeal lies thereto in s. 115 Code of Civil Procedure it was urged that the High Courts jurisdiction to entertain a petition in revision companyld be exercised only if numberappeal lay from the final order passed in the proceeding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'in which no appeal lies thereto' refers to no direct appeal from the impugned order itself, not final decree; rejects Rajasthan High Court precedents as erroneous; avoids undue restriction on salutary jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The trial court's order holding the suit not maintainable falls within clause (c) of s.115 CPC as it was passed illegally or with material irregularity.

anchor.surface_text: By the order passed by the Court of First Instance on the third issue it was held that the suit filed by Dillon was number maintainable. That decision, in our judgment, affected the rights and obligations of the parties directly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court decided mixed law-fact issue without evidence, assuming defendant's pleas true; denied jurisdiction to entertain suit; supervisory power to correct jurisdictional errors.

holdings.text: Under Order 14 Rule 2 CPC, a court has no jurisdiction to try mixed issues of law and fact as preliminary issues if the whole suit cannot be disposed of thereby.

anchor.surface_text: Under 0. 14 r. 2, Code of Civil Procedure, where issues both of law and of fact arise in the same suit, and the Court is of opinion that the case or any part thereof may be disposed of on the issues of law only, it shall try those issues first...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction limited to pure law issues where suit disposable thereon; mixed issues lead to lop-sided trial; applied to maintainability depending on factual ownership of funds.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in setting aside the trial court's order and directing the suit to be heard on merits without holding it non-maintainable at preliminary stage.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in setting aside the order passed by the Trial Court and in holding that without investigation as to the respective claims made by the parties by their pleadings on the matters in dispute the suit companyld number be held number maintainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court erred by assuming facts without evidence; requires trial on whether advances were personal loans or partnership funds; no final view on merits.

holdings.text: The appeal is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All grounds challenging High Court's revisional order rejected; trial court order set aside correctly.

holdings.text: Suits by Dillon are to recover personal loans advanced from joint account to Khanna, not for partnership contribution during winding up.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the opinion that the suits were plainly to recover the amounts borrowed by Khanna from the joint account. The High Court was right in this. Under the companypromise, Dillon was required to recover the assists...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under compromise, Dillon had power of attorney and disposal rights after liabilities; Khanna had no share except oversight; borrowing thus personal (Hidayatullah J. opinion).

anchor.surface_text: One view which is accepted by a majority of the High Courts is that the expression case includes an interlocutory proceeding relating to the rights and obligations of the parties, and the expression record of any case includes so much of the proceeding as relates to the order disposing of the interlocutory proceeding.
